text: Yes, definitely. I think it was a great time to start a career. Enormous experience that you can only get in a lifetime. I think going pre-crisis, the reasons are known. You can read a few books. And from an insider point of view, I think what happened is greed, of course. I think going back to 2000, after the economic slowdown, investment banking was looking for new opportunities to enter the field. To start creating new products that were also demanded by investors. At that time, we also had a period of low interest rates. So everyone was looking for risk, to take risk. And of course, investment banking saw an opportunity. And the idea is simple. If you take what this portfolio theory tells us all about. If you take something that's uncorrelated, you can remove idiosyncratic risk. Idiosyncratic risk can be linearly reduced in a number of your instruments. That was all about creating credit default tranches or mortgage bonds. And then, of course, what happened? It was still not enough. So people, I mean, if you say, normally, credit defaults, the spread on corporate bonds is maybe 100 basis points. In normal times, it goes to 50 basis points. So at a certain point, it was not enough. People wanted to have, say, 2-3% of LIBOR. Investment banking came up with a solution. So effectively, you take, say, mortgages. It started with, say, triple-taught mortgages and then went to more subprime mortgages. But the idea is simple. So you take a few mortgages. You bond them into a special utility vehicle. And the top part will get like AAA rating because it's very rare that everything would default in your pool. So what happened? There was big demand from, say, institutionals. And the bank filled the niche. At certain point, though, you need to do origination of mortgages or facet-backed securities. And at a certain point, it was replaced just by synthetic securities. So instead of, say, giving someone a loan and structuring into a mortgage bond, you just reference. And with reference, the problem is that you can reference multiple securities. So one mortgage could be referenced by hundreds of synthetic bonds. And on banking side, then it became a machine that unfortunately you need an inventory. Bank ended up having inventory. And of course, when everything goes up and if you keep an inventory of risky stuff, it's okay. You can make extra money. But the problem started with liquidity. Once liquidity dries out, you cannot sell your inventory. It starts draining your balance sheet. It's what happens in 2007. And then in the end, you have too much inventory. On top of that, example was with several banks that their treasury department invested in the very same AAA securities that started to lose in value. It was both on liability and on asset side that you get double-heat. But going to specifics. So I'm going to go specifically to say modeling because my role was always structure strategist. I develop models. I was responsible for giving accurate prices for managing the risk and to give support. And what happened actually interesting was also oversight. So imagine simple credit derivatives index would refer a simple way to understand these securities. It's like ATF. You have ATF on cash bonds. So ATF will reference several underlying bonds. And for risk perspective, if you want to say compute some credit duration or some sensitivity to credit, you need to price individual securities. And of course, if they are defaultable securities, it can happen that one of the bonds defaults and it should not affect your pricing. It just is nothing. But actually, the whole derivatives at one of the biggest broker dealers was not able to account for defaulted names. So in fact, a company could default and you still have bonds. And you know that there must be some pre-recovery before the market participants settle the recovery, maybe a few months. Bonds are still there, but you cannot price it. That was all. So you have oversight. Effectively, you want to put, say, going back to our ATF example, you want to put value of zero. But you cannot because it's a contract. So another thing to try, you want to put duration to zero. Then you still can compute your risk. And to put duration to zero, there is one way. You just bump the spreads. You can put a spread, maybe two or three thousand. Then the bond will have zero value. It's what we did. So to tell you this. But in Shinsa, like, say, biggest learning experience is always be susceptible to models. The model is only as good as first the assumptions that you assume. And the second is market, say, market prices. If you assume that you can't say you can use. So model always applied for more liquid securities, like what we are talking. Say, cash bond is a liquid security. And if you say I can't interpret, if I use a liquid securities like credit default swap and treasury curve, in practice, I can replicate. I can replicate the fair value of this bond. But given that it's liquid, the market is liquid enough. And what actually another example of what happened in COO8, exactly this token convertible arbitrage. Or even cash arbitrage. If you say if I'm long bond and I buy protection, I'm neutralizing. So I can also hedge my treasury for. And what I am after is a spread. It's been yield that I get on cash bond, which has some several components. It may be callable bond. So OIS is typically higher than I would pay to protect it. But what actually happened in COO8. There was wide, wide spread, almost 5-6% of several bonds. Meaning that if you owe cash bond, you would be at disadvantage. Even though you would be hedged with CDS. But because CDS price swaps were more liquid than the underlying bonds, you could have negative P&L. Even though you would be hedged. So to summarize. Always be critical of model. And always be critical of what you fit into it. Your model. Is there a recovery plan? If say the market was frozen and I still need to price my securities. Is your model allows for that or not?
